bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Herbert Joseph Spinden, February 5, 1930

div1.p: [Carter] asks Spinden to provide the page numbers of Mayan source references to verify historical statements made in the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Herbert Joseph Spinden, February 5, 1930
div1.opener:
Book
Bibliography
Spinden
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
February 5, 1930.
Dr. Herbert J. Spinden,
Peabody Museum,
Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Dear Doctor Spinden:
div1.p:
You recollect, I am sure, my Father, the late Assistant Sur-
Geon General Henry Rose Carter, who often spoke of how much he had
received of interest and profit from the data you so generously furnish-
ed him, both verbally, at your one meeting, and subsequently by mail,
re the early history of Mexico.

Since Father's death I have, for some time, been engaged on work,
for the Rockefeller Foundation, in connection with the bibliography of
his History of Yellow Fever. In this work I have come across some ref-
erences for which, as you pre-eminent in that field, I am coming to you
for assistance.

1: Re the date of the beginning of the wanderings of the
Chichemecs, I have been referred to the statement that it is “variously
given as (a) from 271 A. D. to (b) 1064 A. D.

(a) The first date “(271) “is that given by the Codex of Ixtlil-
xochoitl (1892) and “(b) the second” (1064) “by the Anales de Chimalpahin,
which” date (1064 A. D.) “is the one generally accepted.”

(a) Can you give me (1) a short quotation, if possible and (b)
pagination for thise quotation (this latterpagination especially) to the effect that
the wanderings of the Chichemecs began in 271 A. D., according to the
Codex of Ixtlilxochitl?

(b) Is there a statement anywhere in the Anales of Chimalpahin
to the effect that the wanderings of the Chichemecs began in 1064? I
I
-2-
have been unable to find such a statement, although, of course, I am
familiar with Rémi-Siméon's quotation from these Anales (p.xxx) in
his introduction thereto re the fact that the Ancient Chichemecs--estab-
lished themselves in a place called Teocolhuacan-Aztlan in the year
50 A. D. This also, of course

I should be very grateful if you could refer me to any pagination
in this book giving the date (1064..or another if this is not correct)
at which the Chichemecs are supposed to have begun thieir wanderings
from the above.

(c) Is 1064 the date “generally accepted” for the beginnings
of the wanderings of the Chichemecs?

I am neither an archaeologist nor an anthropologist, but what I
have read on this very indefinite matter makes me hesitate to accept
the statement without consulting you.

Of course the Provisional Scheme of Dating in Joyce's Mexican
Archaeology gives the fall of Tula as 1064 A. D., but as to when
Xolotl arrived with the Chichemecs in itstheir migration of conquest...quien
sabe?

Of course, I am not trying to settle (or ask you to settle) the
question, I merely want the quotations& pagination re (a) and (b) and
your authoritative statement as to whether (c) is correct in giving 1064
as the date generally accepted for the beginning of these migrations and,
if not (c') what is?

11: Simply for my own information, not for the bibliography,
Will you be so good as to tell me the significance of the term “Dios lae,”
which occurs so often in Gordon's photostat of the Book of Chilam Balam of
Chumayel? Or does the word “lae” have the same meaning (and what meaning?)
when used without Dios?

With highest esteem and hoping much that you are in the States
States
-3-
at present, as I am really very anxious to have the benefit of your
knowledge and kindly help before we send our MS to the printer.
